## Some rudimentary analysis in Markdown

This is an R Markdown document. Markdown is a simple formatting syntax for authoring HTML, PDF, and MS Word documents. For more details on using R Markdown see <http://rmarkdown.rstudio.com>.

### Summary statistics

```{r}
dt$event <- as.factor(dt$event)
summary(dt)
```

```{r}
table(dt$compound, useNA = "always")
```


### Plots

```{r}
dt_eng <- dt %>%
  filter(language == "en")
hist(dt_eng$compound)
```

```{r}
dt_eng_nonzero <- dt %>%
  filter(language == "en" & compound != 0)
hist(dt_eng_nonzero$compound)
```
```{r}
dt_eng <- dt %>%
  filter(language == "en")
hist(dt_eng$polarity)
```
```{r}
dt_eng_nonzero_p <- dt %>%
  filter(language == "en" & polarity != 0)
hist(dt_eng_nonzero_p$polarity)
```

```{r}         
table(dt$language, useNA = "always")
```
```{r}
summary(dt_eng)
```

```{r}

ggplot(dt_eng, aes(x = event)) +
  geom_bar() + 
  ggtitle('Count of tweets')

```




```{r}
# histograms
ggplot(dt_eng_nonzero, aes(x=compound, color=event)) +
  geom_histogram(fill="lightblue", alpha=0.5) + ggtitle('Count of sentiment score')
#position="identity"

```
